Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for ACM HotMobile 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support students at U.S. institutions to attend the Seventeenth Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2016). HotMobile, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, will be held in February, 2016 in St. Augustine, FL. HotMobile 2016 is an important workshop targeting mobile computing and system integration fields and attending this event will benefit the scientific progress of the student's research. The exposure to the technical content of HotMobile 2016 will inspire students to address the tough problems in their respective fields, with a long-term benefit of scientific advances in these types of networks.

Priority will be given to students who will benefit from attending this workshop, but are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding. In addition, applications from female and underrepresented groups in networking research will be strongly encouraged. Up to fourteen students will receive travel grants from this award to attend HotMobile 2016.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant (partially) supported fourteen graduate students at U.S. institutions to attend the Sixteenth Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications (ACM HotMobile 2016). HotMobile, sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE, is a premier workshop in the field of mobile computing, and the 2016 edition was held on February 23-24, 2016 in St. Augustine, Florida. The workshop offered a wide variety of technical activities, including keynote presentations, research paper presentation, poster session, and demos. The workshop values results and insights obtained from working implementations more highly than those obtained solely from simulations. The research and development results reported in HotMobile workshops span multiple disciplines, including wireless communication, mobile applications, wearable computing, vehicular wireless systems, personal area networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, data management, scheduling, sensors, security and privacy.

A small travel grants committee reviewed a total of nineteen applications. The committee members independently ranked the applications for awarding support, and then participateed in a workshop call to determine the final list of awardees. Student awardees were exposed to the start-of-the-art in the field of mobile systems, applications and services. They had the opportunity to interact with both distinguished researchers and fellow undergraduate and graduate students from other institutions. The informal opportunities for discussion have the potential to shape the future careers of the students.
